page.title: 03DALRY(KIRK) ECOLOGY
page.content: The area, one of an equable though damp climate with frequently more than 50 inches of rain a year, is noted for its wild life. It is under the flight path of migrating birds, notably geese and swans.These are often seen grazing on their flight to and from the Arctic. As pesticides are rarely used, there is a wealth of indigenous wildlife. The flora includes orchids, broom and many varieties of fern. The rich fauna includes foxes, rabbits, moles,feral mink and the occasional otter.There are also airborne animals, such as butterflies and bats, and many birds of prey such as henharriers and eagles. The Southern Upland Way, from Portpatrick to Cockburn's Path,crosses the Ken by footbridge, upstream from the older and often flooded crossing place at the 'Stepping Stones'.
